unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Interpreting $T$-Interval
question_text: A television programmer at a local news station surveyed the last $30$ weekday nights and recorded the number of viewers on the $10$ p.m. news. The programmer constructed a one-sample T-interval to find that there is somewhere between $470{,}000$ to $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ with $95\%$ confidence. Which of the following statements could be valid interpretations of the interval?

choices.text: There is a 2.5 % 2.5 % probability that more than 520,000 viewers 520,000 viewers watch the weekday nightly news.
There are most likely somewhere near 500,000 viewers 500,000 viewers watching the weekday nightly news.
There is a 95 % 95 % chance that between 470,000 470,000 and 520,000 viewers 520,000 viewers watch the weekday nightly news on any given night.
About 95 % 95 % of nights, this network has between 470,000 470,000 and 520,000 viewers 520,000 viewers watching the weekday nightly news.
In the long run, 95 % 95 % of people watch the weekday nightly news in this community.
